ca.mcgill.ecse211.project

Class ColorDetection

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.mcgill.ecse211.project.ColorDetection

  • public class ColorDetection
extends java.lang.Object
    This class detects the color of an object. To minimize the undesirable variations in sensor recordings, this class will average several color samples, normalize its RGB value and then compare it to experimental data acquired beforehand. The error is modeled as normal distributions and so the color is determined by selecting the smallest z-score.
    Author:
    Norman Kong, Kaustav Das Sharma, Ryan Au

    • Method Detail

      • getColorSamples

        public static float[] getColorSamples(int numSamples)
        Takes in 20 color samples and returns their average.
        Returns:
        an array that stores the mean RGB value.

      • determineColor

        public static java.lang.String determineColor(float[] x)
        Determines the color of a given RGB value based on a z-score calculation.
        Parameters:
        x - A given RGB value stored in a float array of the form [R value, G value, B value].
        Returns:
        Returns the color of the given RGB value as a String.

      • calcZScore

        public static float calcZScore(float[] sample,
               float[] mean,
               float[] std)
        Calculates the average z-score of an RGB sample given its mean and standard deviation from a normal distribution.
        Parameters:
        sample - A color sample.
        mean - The mean for the sample's normal distribution.
        std - The standard deviation of the sample's normal distribution.
        Returns:
        A z-score of the RGB values (averaged) for the given sample.

      • getObjectColor

        public static java.lang.String getObjectColor()
        Returns object color as a String name.
        Returns:
        None, Green, Orange, Blue, Yellow, or Ground
